Award.AwardTitle: Modeling, Analysis, Computation and Experiments of Two-Component Bose-Einstein Condensates
Award.AbstractNarration: Carretero<br/>DMS-0806762<br/><br/> The goal of the project is to shed light on two-component<br/>Bose-Einstein Condensates (BECs) and how they differ from their<br/>single-component counterparts. The investigator and his<br/>colleagues aim to redefine the way in which modeling and analysis<br/>are developed in such systems by introducing some fundamental<br/>physical processes that were not included in presently employed<br/>models. More specifically, the team of researchers plans to:<br/> (a) develop a new model for two-component BECs, by augmenting<br/>existing models to account for processes such as inter-atomic<br/>interaction losses and higher-order magnetic (Zeeman) effects;<br/> (b) benchmark the model, by testing it in a variety of<br/>situations where the total number of atoms or ratio of atoms<br/>changes between the two components and comparing it against the<br/>newly developed partial differential equation model;<br/> (c) analyze the model mathematically by means of Galerkin<br/>projections and Lyapunov-Schmidt reductions to study finite<br/>dimensional approximations of the dynamics, whereby the existence<br/>and stability of solutions are studied and control strategies are<br/>employed to stabilize potentially unstable solution<br/>configurations;<br/> (d) produce a computational platform that enables the study of<br/>existence, stability and nonlinear dynamics of multi-component,<br/>high-dimensional variants of the nonlinear Schrodinger equations<br/>that are the key mathematical ingredient in the modeling of such<br/>atomic systems. In the process, spatially/temporally adaptive<br/>and/or parallel integrators are produced for time-stepping<br/>purposes and iterative methods are developed in order to analyze<br/>the linear stability problem around steady state solutions. <br/><br/> This project presents a route to systematically quantify the<br/>quantum dynamics at the lowest temperatures that arise in the<br/>Universe, namely in the recently created new form of matter<br/>represented by Bose-Einstein condensates (whose formation was<br/>awarded with the 2001 Nobel prize in Physics and whose<br/>properties, such as superfluidity, were intimately connected to<br/>the Nobel prize in Physics in 2003). The investigator and his<br/>colleagues form an interdisciplinary team to directly monitor<br/>this state of matter in the laboratory, to model the system at<br/>the physical level, to explore the resulting features at the<br/>mathematical level, and finally to fully visualize the<br/>three-dimensional dynamics of such complex systems. A continuous<br/>feedback between all the above stages is intended to ascertain<br/>not only a qualitative but also a quantitative understanding of<br/>such atomic physics systems, such as gases of rubidium, sodium<br/>and other alkali vapors. The multi-species systems under study<br/>present a wealth of opportunities for future applications,<br/>ranging from the controllable formation of ultracold microscopic<br/>patterns (in a form of "quantum lithography") to the realization<br/>of quantum gates and switches, that, in turn, aim towards the<br/>longer term goal of enabling quantum computation. <br/>
